channel.title: Venezuela: the new Cuba
channel.description:
http://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE51D28Z20090216
Chavez, whose current term ends in 2013, has already been in power for 10 years and his win in this referendum win helps clear the way for him to fulfill stated his declared goal of ruling for decades.
Chavez has 'won' the right to allow re-election. Therefore, like his buddy Castro in Cuba, he will remain at power till' death. oh and for those who haven't seen Chavez at his best: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X3Kzbo7tNLg

item.title: Venezuela: the new Cuba
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:19, topic:262439”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=346573.msg2672758#msg2672758 date=1234898045]

Are you born a rebel or do normal citizens turn into rebels? I think its the latter.

A rebel fights against the rules/government. So do you think a rebel will follow the rules?

And the ‘turning point’ where a normal citizen becomes a rebel isn’t influenced by the right to bear arms. Someone who wants to rebel but doesn’t have to guts to get a weapon when it’s illegal won’t have the guts to actually rebel when he does have the right to bear arms.
[/quote]

I’m saying if the government controls all of the guns it would be extremely hard to get them. If the people have the right to bear arms, such as here in America, the government would not even try to oppress the people because they know it would be impossible. The right to bear arms protects all the other rights and keeps the government in check.[/quote]

But that’s not true. Here in the Netherlands we don’t have the right to bear arms. Only members of shooting clubs are allowed to have one in a safe, and it has to be registered. But the government doesn’t control the guns, only the registered ones. I doubt a rebel will buy a registered gun, as the seller has to notify the government who bought the gun from him. So they’ll keep track of the gun. Rebels buy illegal guns, and the government won’t know about it.

Read full topic

item.title: Venezuela: the new Cuba
item.dc:creator: @Scrubs Scrubs
item.description:
@Scrubs wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:14, topic:262439”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=346573.msg2672007#msg2672007 date=1234872225]

I don’t like how everyone sees this as a negative thing. Hugo Chavez is one of our times greatest leaders.

Well, dictatorship is the best way to actually become a true Communist country. Thing is, most dictators forget about that and hold on to their power.
[/quote]Venezuela isn’t a communist country, they have a Socialistic system with direct-democracy.[/quote]
Give him a couple of years. I can already see Venezuela turning into a Cuba with lots of oil moneys.

Read full topic

item.title: Venezuela: the new Cuba
item.dc:creator: @Bebemycat2 Bebe
item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

I was speaking directly about Venezuela in my post. For them nonviolence would be ideal, I’m not saying that is true in all cases.

Read full topic

item.title: Venezuela: the new Cuba
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:17, topic:262439”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=346573.msg2672698#msg2672698 date=1234896285]
Are you born a rebel or do normal citizens turn into rebels? I think its the latter.
[/quote]

A rebel fights against the rules/government. So do you think a rebel will follow the rules?

And the ‘turning point’ where a normal citizen becomes a rebel isn’t influenced by the right to bear arms. Someone who wants to rebel but doesn’t have to guts to get a weapon when it’s illegal won’t have the guts to actually rebel when he does have the right to bear arms.[/quote]

I’m saying if the government controls all of the guns it would be extremely hard to get them. If the people have the right to bear arms, such as here in America, the government would not even try to oppress the people because they know it would be impossible. The right to bear arms protects all the other rights and keeps the government in check.

[quote=“Bebe, post:18, topic:262439”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=346573.msg2671547#msg2671547 date=1234841085]

This is what happens when you don’t have the right to bear arms. It’s been demonstrated time and time again, you’ve all heard the saying those who are ignorant of history are doomed to repeat it, well here it is in action.

How the fuck is that going to help?

Dictators don’t go over well when the people they mean to rule are all armed.

That’s not true at all. Just because the people are armed doesn’t mean they have the mental capacity or even the means to surmount oppression by a dictator.

But if they aren’t armed, nothing else matters, they are just screwed.
[/quote]
There are ways to make changes without resorting to violence. Nonviolent methods of creating change are also less devastation for a country or people especially when about a third of Venezuelans lack adequate sanitation and they are struggling with poverty issues. Civil unrest resulting in violence would devastate Venezuela and only hurt the citizens.[/quote]

There aren’t always non-violent ways when under a dictatorship, could the jews in nazi germany non-violently oppose what was being done to them?

Read full topic

That’s not true at all. Just because the people are armed doesn’t mean they have the mental capacity or even the means to surmount oppression by a dictator.

There are ways to make changes without resorting to violence. Nonviolent methods of creating change are also less devastation for a country or people especially when about a third of Venezuelans lack adequate sanitation and they are struggling with poverty issues. Civil unrest resulting in violence would devastate Venezuela and only hurt the citizens.

item.description:
@Not_X_A_Alex wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:15, topic:262439”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=346573.msg2671914#msg2671914 date=1234865632]

This is what happens when you don’t have the right to bear arms. It’s been demonstrated time and time again, you’ve all heard the saying those who are ignorant of history are doomed to repeat it, well here it is in action.

How the fuck is that going to help?

Dictators don’t go over well when the people they mean to rule are all armed.

That’s not true at all. Just because the people are armed doesn’t mean they have the mental capacity or even the means to surmount oppression by a dictator.

But if they aren’t armed, nothing else matters, they are just screwed.

Normal citizens won’t start a rebellion. Rebels will (I see how that is confusing, but I hope you understand me). There probably are a shitload of rebellion groups in Venezuela. But there are none in the US. If rebels want a gun, they get a gun.
[/quote]

Are you born a rebel or do normal citizens turn into rebels? I think its the latter.[/quote]
I think its a switch. Like terrorism… there are other country terrorists then the domestic terrorists because they hate the goverment

item.title: Venezuela: the new Cuba
item.dc:creator: @Scrubs Scrubs
item.description:
@Scrubs wrote:

U.S. – 16 Feb 09

Chavez hails Venezuela vote win slammed by rivals

Hugo Chavez and his supporters celebrated an election victory that allows him to...

Chavez, whose current term ends in 2013, has already been in power for 10 years and his win in this referendum win helps clear the way for him to fulfill stated his declared goal of ruling for decades.

Chavez has ‘won’ the right to allow re-election. Therefore, like his buddy Castro in Cuba, he will remain at power till’ death.

oh and for those who haven’t seen Chavez at his best: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X3Kzbo7tNLg

Read full topic
